Mathematical Operations¶

Mathematical and Convenience functions ease data manipulation for logic.

TBD

analytics.foundation.counts(ar: List[StringOrFloat], normalize: bool = False) → Dict[StringOrFloat, float][source]¶

Gets proportions of each :param ar: :param normalize:

Returns

Return type

Dict[StringOrFloat, float]

Examples

>>> counts([])
{}
>>> counts(['a', 'a', 'a','b'])
{'a': 0.75, 'b': 0.25}
>>> counts([1, 1, 1, 2])
{1: 0.75, 2: 0.25}
>>> counts([1, 1, 1, 2])
{1: 0.75, 2: 0.25}
analytics.foundation.map_values(values: List[float], value_type: src.objects.QuestionType)[source]¶

Maps values from one numeric range to a different numeric range. Currently, mapping is to defined for 1-to-10 or 1-to-5 ranges to “Semantic Buckets” (Positive, Negative, or Neutral).

TODO: Add parameter for mapping lambda and to_type. TODO: Hard-coded to map 1-to-10 or 1-to-5 values to “Semantic Buckets”.

Parameters

  • values – Input data

  • value_type – Type of

Returns

Numeric values on different scale. Currently hard-coded to legacy semantic bucket scale.

Return type

List[float]

analytics.foundation.percent_satisfying_condition(ar: List[float], condition: Callable) → Optional[float][source]¶

Percent of values in an array that satisfy condition.

Parameters

  • ar – List of numeric values

  • condition – Calculates percent of values that satisfy this condition.

Returns

  • Percentage (between 0 and 1, inclusive) if x has 1 or more elements. Otherwise it returns

  • None.

Examples

>>> greater_than_two = lambda x: x > 2
>>> percent_satisfying_condition([1, 2, 3, 4], greater_than_two)
0.5
>>> greater_than_four = lambda x: x > 4
>>> percent_satisfying_condition([1, 2, 3, 4], greater_than_four)
0.0
>>> percent_satisfying_condition([], greater_than_four)
